ArticleTitle.sentence: The role of nuclear factor-kappa B in cytokine gene regulation.

event.clue: The role of nuclear factor-kappa B in cytokine gene regulation.

AbstractText.sentence: Transcription factors are DNA-binding proteins that regulate gene expression.

event.clue: Transcription factors are DNA-binding proteins that regulate gene expression.
Transcription factors are DNA-binding proteins that regulate gene expression.

AbstractText.sentence: Nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kappa B) is a critical transcription factor for maximal expression of many cytokines that are involved in the pathogenesis of inflammatory diseases, such as adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and sepsis syndrome.

event.clue: Nuclear factor-kappa B (NF-kappa B) is a critical transcription factor for maximal expression of many cytokines that are involved in the pathogenesis of inflammatory diseases, such as adult respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and sepsis syndrome.

AbstractText.sentence: Activation and regulation of NF-kappa B are tightly controlled by a group of inhibitory proteins (I kappa B) that sequester NF-kappa B in the cytoplasm of immune/inflammatory effector cells.

AbstractText.sentence: Liberated NF-kappa B migrates to the nucleus, where it binds to specific promoter sites and activates gene transcription.

AbstractText.sentence: The activation of NF-kappa B initiates both extracellular and intracellular regulatory events that result in autoregulation of the inflammatory cascade through modulation of NF-kappa B activation.

AbstractText.sentence: Recently, activation of NF-kappa B has been linked to ARDS and has been shown to be a critical proximal step in the initiation of neutrophilic inflammation in animal models.

AbstractText.sentence: Activation of NF-kappa B can be inhibited in vivo by treatment with antioxidants, corticosteroids, and the induction of endotoxin tolerance.
